text: The deepest hole ever drilled is the Kola Superdeep Borehole in Russia at 12.3 km — it took 20 years to drill and temperatures at the bottom reached 180°C.
There's enough gold dissolved in the world's oceans to give every person 9 pounds of gold, but it's too diluted to extract economically.
The Earth's core is as hot as the surface of the Sun — about 5,400°C.
Yellowstone's supervolcano has enough magma to fill the Grand Canyon 11 times over and erupts catastrophically every 600,000 years — it's overdue.
Antarctica was once a tropical rainforest, and fossils of palm trees and dinosaurs have been found there.
The Earth's magnetic poles flip roughly every 200,000-300,000 years — the last flip was 780,000 years ago, so we're overdue.
The Himalayas grow about 1 cm per year due to the Indian subcontinent still crashing into Asia.
Lake Baikal in Russia contains 22% of the world's fresh surface water — more than all the Great Lakes combined.
The Dead Sea is so salty that you can float in it effortlessly, but it's also shrinking by about 3 feet per year.
Mount Everest grows about 4mm per year and is still rising due to tectonic forces.
The Pacific Ocean is shrinking by about an inch per year while the Atlantic Ocean is getting wider.
There's a hidden continent called Zealandia that's 94% submerged beneath the Pacific Ocean.
The Mariana Trench is so deep that if Mount Everest were placed at its bottom, the peak would still be over a mile underwater.
Approximately 80% of volcanic eruptions happen underwater, and we've explored less than 5% of the ocean floor.
The Sahara Desert was a lush, green savanna with lakes and rivers just 6,000 years ago.
There's a cave in Mexico called the Cave of Crystals containing gypsum crystals up to 12 meters long — the largest natural crystals ever found.
Earthquakes can make gold appear — sudden pressure drops during quakes cause water in rock faults to vaporize, depositing gold.
The Amazon River once flowed into the Pacific Ocean before the Andes Mountains rose up and reversed its direction.
The Great Blue Hole in Belize is a perfectly circular underwater sinkhole 318 meters across and 124 meters deep.
Plate tectonics didn't start until about a billion years after Earth formed — the early Earth had a single solid shell.
The oldest rocks on Earth are about 4.4 billion years old, found in Western Australia.
Lightning strikes Earth about 8 million times per day, and a single bolt can heat the air to 30,000 Kelvin.
The 1883 eruption of Krakatoa was heard 3,000 miles away and the sound circled the Earth four times.
There's a 'Door to Hell' in Turkmenistan — a burning natural gas crater that's been on fire since 1971.
The driest place on Earth isn't the Sahara — it's the Dry Valleys of Antarctica, which haven't seen rain for 2 million years.
The pressure at the bottom of the ocean is so intense it would crush a human body instantly — yet life thrives there.
Mount Chimborazo in Ecuador is technically 'taller' than Everest if measured from Earth's center, due to the planet's equatorial bulge.
The Earth's crust is proportionally thinner than an eggshell compared to the planet's size.
There are underwater rivers and lakes at the bottom of the ocean, formed by dense salty water flowing along the seafloor.
The Moho discontinuity marks where Earth's crust ends and mantle begins — no human has ever reached it.
A cubic mile of seawater contains about 25 pounds of gold and 45 million pounds of salt.
The 2011 Japan earthquake was so powerful it shifted Earth's axis by 4 inches and shortened the day by 1.8 microseconds.
Angel Falls in Venezuela is so tall (979 meters) that water turns to mist before reaching the bottom.
Blood Falls in Antarctica seeps iron-rich water that looks exactly like blood pouring from a glacier.
The Danakil Depression in Ethiopia is the hottest inhabited place on Earth with average temperatures of 34.4°C.
Lava flows can reach temperatures of 1,200°C — hot enough to melt glass and some metals.
The Earth's inner core spins faster than the rest of the planet, completing an extra rotation every 400 years.
Petrified lightning, called fulgurite, forms when lightning strikes sand and fuses it into glass tubes.
There's a pink lake in Australia called Lake Hillier whose color has never been fully explained.
The Richat Structure in Mauritania is a 50-km-wide circular formation visible from space, once thought to be an impact crater but now believed to be eroded rock.
Oil and coal are made from ancient organisms — a gallon of gasoline required about 98 tons of prehistoric plant material.
The world's largest cave passage is in Vietnam's Hang Son Doong, big enough to fit a 40-story building.
Volcanic lightning occurs when ash particles collide and create static electricity during eruptions.
The Hawaiian Islands are moving northwest at about 7-9 cm per year due to plate tectonics.
Diamonds can form in just minutes under the extreme pressures of asteroid impacts.
Mount Erebus in Antarctica has a permanent lava lake and is the southernmost active volcano on Earth.
Underground fires can burn for decades or centuries — the Centralia mine fire in Pennsylvania has burned since 1962.
The oldest water on Earth was found 2 miles underground in Canada and is about 2 billion years old.
Pumice is the only rock that floats on water because it's full of gas bubbles from volcanic eruptions.
The Mid-Atlantic Ridge is the longest mountain range on Earth at 65,000 km, but it's almost entirely underwater.
